comments.author: James Matthew Neeland

comments.text:
+Blk Dominican Thank you for that.I am a lover of classic cinema and a big 
fan of Miss Crawford's. I can not countenance the put-upon snobbery that 
she was not an actress but a mere movie star, a mere "beautifully 
bone-structured personality." I agree with Steven Spielberg, whose first 
major assignment was to direct Crawford in the "Eyes" segment on Rod 
Serling's "Night Gallery" pilot (1969) : "She did not have a great range, 
yet within that range, she was without peer and could out-act all of her 
contemporaries."

Over the years, I have studied many pieces, read many books, visited many 
websites.
Here are a sampling of some excellent biographical information on Miss 
Crawford, from Bob Thomas to Saun Considine and more.


http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1665050.Joan_Crawford



http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/374652.Bette_and_Joan



http://www.joancrawfordbest.com/menupage.htm



http://www.joancrawfordbest.com/books.htm



I hope these provide you with much great research and pleasure.


You have an excellent day.
comments.author: James Matthew Neeland

comments.text: +James Matthew Neeland I'm a fan of yours now too...:)

the top of the list - i really became a fan after watching Mommie Dearest! 
Thank you sooooo much for this information - how did you find all this out 
- again amazing work
...
comments.author: Blk Dominican

comments.text:
+Blk Dominican You have such reverence for Miss Crawford, Bill. It's nice 
to see her fans still as loyal and loving as ever.
When Joan Crawford married Alfred Nu Steele in 1955, Pepsi-Cola was on the 
verge of going international, after a very successful domestic run under 
Steele. Steele could do no wrong, as far as Pepsi was concerned.
Upon marrying, Crawford became a roving ambassador-in-glamor for the soft 
drink company, opening bottling plants, promoting the product wherever and 
however she could ( even product placement spots within her later films - 
all hits with the "Pepsi generation") and essentially providing Pepsi with 
more press than advertizing dollars could have garnered. Wherever she went, 
Pepsi-Cola followed - and so did the press. Lots of it. When Al Steele 
passed on from a coronary in 1959, just shy of the couple's fourth wedding 
anniversary, his personal financial affairs were somewhat messy, though not 
as it relates to his employer. Steele did, in fact, take out loans to both 
finance the reconstruction of the East 69th Street duplex penthouse and for 
living expenses during the process. One of the people from whom he borrowed 
money was Joan, who liquidated her savings and borrowed against her 
insurance policies and took his stock options/real property stock and other 
assets as collateral. The loan he had taken from Pepsi had been repaid by 
the time of his death. He was on salary, and Joan still held substantial 
stock in lieu of the loans she had made to Steele. ( His will was not 
settled in New York probate until 1966. ) What Pepsi-Cola was trying to do 
was reclaim the penthouse as company property, for there had been rumblings 
from shareholders about the famous couple's high-flying lifestyle and trips 
abroad to promote the product. Because Pepsi had provided Steele with loans 
solely for the purpose ( or so they asserted ) of Mr. & Mrs. Steele using 
the penthouse to woo investors and dazzle clients, i.e. strictly business, 
it was reasoned by the Pepsi Board that, after Steele's death and 
Crawford's soon-to-be-disenfranchisement from the company ( or so they 
asserted . . . . ), the East 69th duplex penthouse should revert to the 
company. The value of the home was around $500,000.00, an enormous sum in 
1959, even by Manhattan standards. There was no "ample debt" to be repaid, 
as per the quite dramatic scene above. What Pepsi wanted was to both kick 
Joan Crawford off the Board and out-of the apartment. Joan knew she had to 
work fast. She called Louella Parsons, one of the top Hollywood gossip 
columnists of the time, and gave her the exclusive that she was broke ( 
which, as far as Steele's legacy was concerned, was true, for he had had no 
assets except for the ones Crawford was holding as collateral ) and that 
Pepsi-Cola wanted to toss her into the street . . . . Uh-oh. Bad press. Bad 
press. Well, welcome back, Miss Crawford, on a $50,000.00 annual salary 
plus $40,000.00 expense account, a $12,000.00 annual secretarial account 
and continued stock options ( Bullseye. ) Joan Crawford retained her 
position until she was involuntarily retired ( upon her official 65th 
birthday ) in 1973 by Douglas Kendall ( a man whom Crawford often referred 
to as Fang. ) One wonders, though, where were the fabled jewel collection 
and real estate and other tid-bits of accumulated wealth Joan Crawford had 
apparently amassed during all the cries of poverty. She was savvy. Savvy 
enough to know when NOT to divulge. The movie clip may be entertaining, yet 
it doesn't do justice, I think, to the truly wonderful work Miss Crawford 
was able to do for Pepsi-Cola. She was a working star - not merely an 
extortionist. In closing, let me tell you a great story : When Alfred and 
Joan were looking for a pad in NYC, they applied to an exclusive Manhattan 
co-op but were rejected. Ever the queen, and never to let anybody else 
trump her, Joan had a very large Pepsi-Cola display, all lit-up in red and 
blue, installed within the view of the co-op building that had turned her 
down. That's our Joan.

comments.author: inkey2

comments.text:
+Dré K. B. you said it Dre'.....there are countless great movies the 
critics panned. For example there was a black & white movie from the 
1950s?" Night Of The Hunter" starring Robert Mitchum. The movie did not do 
well in the box office. Now it is considered an artistic film masterpiece 
shown to film students all over the world. At the time it came out the way 
each scene was shot was considered odd, offbeat etc. There is a scene where 
two children are on a boat going down a river and it's hard to tell if it's 
in their dreams or reality. You really should watch it on youtube if you 
like ground breaking movies
comments.author: inkey2

comments.author: Dré K. B.

comments.text:
Not only did she not get an award for this...but this movie was considered 
a "turkey" for years even though it enjoyed limited cult status. In fact 
Faye was so embarassed by it she would refuse to talk about it in 
interviews.
As the years have gone by the movie has enjoyed a slow momentum upward. Now 
it has even become part of the English language ...example....."oh, her 
mother is totally Mommy Dearest". I absolutely loved this movie and I watch 
it again, and again and again.

comments.text:
lies lies lies...even Christina said this film was fictional and a huge 
exaggeration. The director, Frank Perry's, original intention for this film 
was to take elements from all of Joan's movies and put it in one. Instead, 
they ended up with that ^. After, Christina's husband, David Koontz, found 
out Christina embellished a lot of the book (hence the divorce), the 
director & producer didn't take her seriously.﻿

comments.author: Nurse Grace

comments.text:
Thanks, N. Grace. I had forgotten about those! Usually, it's "Don't F*#$# 
with me, fellas!" or anything else from the Boardroom scene, but there are 
many, many other classic, quotable scenes, including the rare steak scene 
in the restaurant ("Tina, flirting can be....taken the wrong WAY. Do you 
understand?") and Tina's expulsion from boarding school ("I should have 
known you'd know where to find The Boys...AND the BOOZE"). lolz. Great 
movie. In my view, one or two of the scenes are genuinely upsetting/hard to 
watch, which only puts the rest of the over.the.top camp into extra.odd 
relief. I could actually do without: "No more wire hangers EVER" because 
both actresses (including young Christina) actually make it look like a 
legitimate child abuse scene. BUT: I will say that if you just lift the 
lines, without having to actually watch the Monster in action, you still 
come up with really groovy Camp: "You live in the most beautiful house in 
Brentwood and you dont care about crease marks from wire hangers, and your 
room looks like some two dollar unfurnished room in some two- bit

comments.text:
Yeah and no. I think this movie is an example of what happens when someone 
as talented as Fay Dunaway is paired up with a talentless director: an 
actor's performance is only as good as their director. Even so there are 
some scenes when you can see where's right on the ball like here. It's a 
shame, but I really would have loved to see the performance she would have 
given if she had the right director to reign her in when she was exploding 
into cartoonish melodrama.
comments.author: Squirrel Fish
